thread.title: Investors tack onto media buy-up plan Gloo Networks
thread.title_full: Investors tack onto media buy-up plan Gloo Networks

title: Investors tack onto media buy-up plan Gloo Networks
text:
+0.16 
Marwyn-backed shell company sets out on £1bn acquistion trail as shares hit AIM 
A shell company that plans to snap up a string of trusted but struggling media brands for up to £1bn each has made its debut on the Alternative Investment Market with backing from major institution. 
Gloo Networks is the latest venture by the investment group Marwyn and has raised an initial pot of £30m to carry out due diligence on its targets. The shares will open at 120p on Tuesday. 
As well as Marwyn, the major shareholders on the first day of trading include Invesco (NYSE: IVZ - news ) , the hedge fund Ruffer, and Standard Life (LSE: SL.L - news ) . They have committed to stumping up more cash when Gloo is ready to sign its first deal, expected within months. 
The team behind the plan, chief executive Rebecca Miskin, a former senior executive at Hearst, and Juan Lopez-Valcarcel, who most recently worked in digital education at Pearson (Xetra: 858266 - news ) , are now hunting the US, UK and Europe for acquisitions. 
It is understood that they hope to buy in the UK first. Gloo will seek to combine “marquee” traditional print or video brands that have yet to make a successful leap to digital distribution, and combine them with technological know-how 
That might mean linking a traditional magazine with apps that make it easy for readers to buy featured products, or a major overhaul of the digital nuts and bolts of the business to gain insights on readers for advertisers, according to people familiar with the strategy. In the long-term Gloo aims to become a sustainable large-scale media group that will seek a transfer to London’s main market. 
The company currently has only one member of staff beyond Ms Miskin and Mr Lopez-Valcarcel, and is headquartered in an attic at Marwyn’s offices, but has access to the investor’s analysts and due diligence resources. 
Marwyn is pursuing a similar strategy in the European telecoms market via Zegona Communications (LSE: ZEG.L - news ) . It listed as a shell in March and last month wrote its first big cheque when it agreed to buy the Spanish operator Telecable de Asturias for €640m.
